## Research questions

::: incremental
Analysis based on **graph theory**, where roads are modeled as **vertices** and **edges**.

1.  How does road connectivity change after being impacted by flooding based on connectivity metrics?
2.  Which healthcare facilities will be most affected by flooding based on accessibility metrics?
3.  Where are the most critical infrastructures located for accessing health facilities to reinforce urban resilience against flooding?
:::

## Edge Betweenness

::: columns

::: {.column width="80%"}

![](/images/laura_map.png)

:::

::: {.column width="20%"}

Significance of the road counting shortest paths

$$
c_{B}(v) = \sum_{\substack{s \neq t \neq v \\ s,t \in V}} \frac{\sigma(s,t|v)}{\sigma(s,t)}
$$
:::

:::

## Closeness

::: columns
::: {.column width="80%"}
![](/images/laura_map.png)
:::

::: {.column width="20%"}
How central to other vertices is a vertex

$$
\text{CN}(v) = \frac{n - 1}{\sum_{w = 1}^{n - 1} d(w, v)}
$$
:::
:::

# Discussion {.smaller}

1. Could changes in road centrality indicate regional vulnerability to flooding?
2. Is weighted sampling based on built-up density a reliable method for modeling people's movement during floods? Would you choose a different approach for origin points?
3. Would you include other points of interest, like schools, shelters, or bus stops, alongside hospitals?
4. Could mapping socioeconomic vulnerabilities by neighborhood alongside centrality metrics help identify key roads during floods?
5. Any suggestions for improving this centrality analysis or additional data to enhance the study?
